Under Grant’s bill, felons must pay all fines, fees and restitution before they earn back the right to vote, an interpretation of the amendment that significantly cracked down how many people would benefit. Opponents of Grant’s bill have sued, and the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit will hear arguments on Tuesday."},{"_id":"SAL5LYXBTNEP3KBJ5CTH5TSG6Q","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[]},"content":"Though he field to run for re-election, Grant appears to have been severing his ties to the area since last year. There's never a shortage of stories about either in Florida. The best ones hold your elected leaders accountable and expose the unelected powers pulling the levers. That's what I'm focused on. I started out covering politics in my home state of Illinois, with stints in Wisconsin, Virginia and Washington, D.C., before settling in Florida in 2015. I'll take the heat over snow any day. County's largest law enforcement agency is closer than it's ever been to having body cameras. Sheriff Bob Gualtieri has long resisted the technology, citing concerns such as cost, records maintenance and redundancy -- the Sheriff's Office is one of the few local agencies with dashboard cameras in all patrol cars. But technological advances, and pro-body camera feedback from the community, have pushed him to reconsider. His change of heart is part of a sea change amid the Tampa Bay area. Once slow to adopt body cameras, major agencies including the Hillsborough County Sheriff's Office and the Clearwater Police Department are now moving forward on body cam The four electric buses will replace four existing diesel buses, which typically average 50,000 miles annually and last an average of 10.2 years, according to a June report from the agency."},{"_id":"3MCOVWYMPBB3LAUCVJ3JBTRJPA","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597263766292},"content":"The agency has seen some cost and environmental savings by switching to compressed natural gas for part of its fleet. That’s an average of 35,600 additional miles traveled per bus."},{"_id":"AHCIBRGHDZCTDIKCXIP4GNRSSI","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597263766293},"content":"The same report said the compressed natural gas buses reduced greenhouse gas emissions at the agency by 2,200 tons and 29,200 barrels of oil."},{"_id":"YF5YPFQVIVE53HVPNVZIY3R5FQ","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597263766294},"content":"Electric buses are expected to go beyond that, with vastly lower greenhouse gas emissions. New York City’s transit authority was predicted to save nearly 500,000 metric tons of carbon dioxide per year if it switched its fleet to all electric, according to a study conducted by Columbia University in 2016 for New York City Transit."},{"_id":"K5VF23OSJNCE7LF57SS4IDBUQM","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597263766295},"content":"Because an electric bus is not as complex as the internal combustion engine in a diesel vehicle, the maintenance costs are expected to be 40 to 50 percent less expensive, the same report found."},{"_id":"4JD7L7UQKJHKTA7ERP7FZC2E4M","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597263766296},"content":"An electric bus lasts an average of 12 years and 500,000 miles, Hillsborough transit agency spokeswoman Carson Chambers said."},{"_id":"GLDWDHH4RRGGVBF24IYQ5N2U3Q","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597263766297},"content":"“For our drivers it will be quiet, less vibration,” transit authority board member Pat Kemp said. “They’ll be wonderful in our community.”"},{"_id":"YJXQTFOPKFFWVGNYFRP2OA2HUI","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597263766298},"content":"Pinellas’ transit agency unveiled its first electric bus two years ago and expects to have four more by the end of this year, Pinellas Suncoast Transit Authority spokeswoman Stephanie Rank said."},{"_id":"23XIRZQJUNE3DNNG2ASNHC64T4","type":"interstitial_link","additional_properties":{"_id":"RBMVZ2C7MVCL3MFZGDOEJVVIV4","comments":[]},"url":"https://www.tampabay.com/news/transportation/masstransit/Pinellas-first-electric-bus-is-here-It-s-free-It-s-in-St-Pete-_172340073/","content":"Pinellas' first electric bus is here. It's free. These issues couldn’t be more important.”"},{"_id":"MDEQWFTMKBF4LJK4BKEQ3LBBSU","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597263766302},"content":"The electric buses can run about 150 miles on one charge and would be used on some of Hillsborough’s most frequented routes, interim chief executive Carolyn House Stewart said."},{"_id":"FVRVXBWZ7FDC7J6NFNBVTUJCAM","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597263766303},"content":"Those include a route from Marion Transit Center to Hillsborough Community College, an east/west route on Cypress Street and a route from Ybor City to Tampa General Hospital on Davis Islands, Chambers said."},{"_id":"KYHQGVUCQZFADLJO2OPUJXUUCU","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597263766304},"content":"In addition to the federal grant, the transit agency and Tampa Electric Co. will provide $2,742,675 — or half of the total project cost — for infrastructure such as underground wiring and charging stations."},{"_id":"NVWQGRBAYBDTTLUEGORRIWDFXY","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597263766305},"content":"Hillsborough’s transit agency will continue to reduce its inventory of diesel-fueled vehicles over the next few years by transitioning to electric buses as funding becomes available, Chambers said."},{"_id":"FNWHEYJKTNAF3DQ55PCE2SMVFY","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597263766306},"content":"Kemp said she’d like to see the agency transition entirely to renewable energy, as other transit authorities in the country have pledged. Kathy Castor will be joined by HART leaders to announce $2.7 million in a grant from the U.S. Department of Transportation to speed HART (Hillsborough Area Regional Transit) into the future of mass transit – a clean system that burns no fuel, generates no pollution and runs nearly silently. The grant will purchase up to four, clean, electric-powered buses and supporting infrastructure. I let you know how new projects will impact your commute and quality of life, while also dissecting complex policies and budgets. My work takes me from bus stops to government meetings to sitting in mind-numbing traffic jams. I’m a proud Hoosier, a slow runner, and a lover of mountains. I studied journalism and political science at Indiana University and earned my master’s at the University of Maryland. I joined the Times in 2012, first covering breaking news in Tampa and east Hillsborough. I attend 9-hour meetings and read traffic studies from the 1960s so you didn’t have to. Stuart</b> represents District 3 in North Hillsborough<i>. </i>But, after two terms on the board, she is running for Clerk of Court. It is an open primary against fellow Democrat Kevin Beckner. Stuart, who early on wanted schools to remain closed until after Labor Day, voted in favor of Davis’s plan on July 23 and against the four-week delay on Aug. 6. She said this week that she feels duty-bound to serve all constituents, those who want to keep their children home and those whose children need to be in school. That position has angered leaders of the teachers’ union, which threw its support to Beckner. On Wednesday, Stuart told the <i>Times:</i> “My position is, we need to adhere to the executive order (issued by Corcoran) and we need to provide equity for all kids, especially our most Shamburger</b> represents District 5, which serves the largest number of low-income and minority communities. A former COVID-19 patient, Shamburger has spoken out about the need to protect those communities hardest hit by the virus. And she has challenged Corcoran on his assertion that reopening is the best way to cure achievement gaps, saying he is using the equity issue as a “Trojan Horse.” Her votes so far: No to the reopening plan on July 23, yes to the four-week postponement on Aug. 6. all over Florida. After 15 years as an editor in the Tampa suburbs I was assigned to cover the Hillsborough public school system, the same one that gave my two children a great education. That last part didn't happen by itself. I was an active volunteer and believe schools should accommodate parents' busy schedules. I’m not a fan of the 3 p.m. parent conference or 10 a.m. PTA meeting! On weekends I play tennis and volunteer at a youth soccer program. Call or email me with your tips about the schools. I use Facebook for family and Twitter for self-promotion. Similar to the unfailingly shrewd investigators of prime-time television, researchers are starting to think they can learn something from that genetic evidence."},{"_id":"2SOC2CUMTJH6RDWF4BQM7F56IU","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597257777913},"content":"Scientists from Florida International University, teaming with colleagues from New College of Florida and a conservation group, have pulled samples of water from Terra Ceia Bay, a popular nursery for blacktip sharks south of the Sunshine Skyway bridge. Filtering that water, they have identified shark DNA, the frequency of which they say roughly corresponds to breeding periods."},{"_id":"PU2BQEURIJAPLJ6RMRX3M3Z6KE","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597257777914},"content":"Unlike a crime drama, though, the point is not to catch a culprit."},{"_id":"NNLOESFYUZFZ5KZQ7USFQ5FKBA","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597257777915},"content":"“It’s going to be about saving sharks from people, really,” said Demian Chapman, a biological sciences professor at Florida International."},{"_id":"GPYGBSX7L5BZZCAPDARKQEDOBI","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597260673358},"content":"The hope is that environmental DNA sampling can provide a safe, affordable and easy way to track shark populations in the future, crucial as regulators try to maintain the health of a species. Blacktips are important to the Gulf of Mexico fishery for their meat and skin. Catches have gone up in recent years, in part because regulators restricted harvesting of another type of shark, said Jayne Gardiner, a New College of Florida biology professor involved in the research. At the seafood counter in Publix, she said, shark meat is now often blacktip."},{"_id":"XTVBGIYPVRGQVIJJMICNQWDWOY","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597257777917},"content":"As their popularity has increased, populations have remained high, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. That is a success, Gardiner said, but not a reason to get complacent on managing the fishery."},{"_id":"IY4RIEVKZFC33HEEAVM6EP3ONY","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597260673360},"content":"Gardiner’s team employs a traditional method, pulling in blacktips using gill nets — banned in Florida for commercial harvesting — while watching closely to make sure other marine animals avoid the trap and keeping count of the sharks. Meanwhile, the Florida International group dips a bottle into the bay to collect two liters of water at a time. They use filters and lab analysis to focus on blacktip DNA. Each filter test, Chapman said, costs about $12. The concurrent surveying is married to see how DNA results match up to population counts."},{"_id":"MI26AGCZ4VCI3IUK3NSIEAEU6U","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597257777919},"content":"“If you can move to something where all you’re doing is sampling water, it really only takes a couple of people to do that,” Gardiner said. By comparison, fishing for sharks demands bigger crews and closer contact with the animals."},{"_id":"7M5VYDXE3BA2DECESP45PEWCP4","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597257777920},"content":"Blacktips can grow to about 6.5 feet in length, according to the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission. They come near shore in schools, feeding on creatures like smaller sharks, crabs and rays. They favor Terra Ceia as a spring nursery, where they give birth to pups before moving south to deeper water. The Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission notes they have also “been implicated in attacks on bathers.”"},{"_id":"WEWHTFWZT5H4ZED2KB6I46ALGE","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597257777921},"content":"That, however, is not the point of keeping count, Chapman said, and water sampling would probably not reduce already “very, very rare attacks.”"},{"_id":"BKFGOBRXFNARLANQ4PVYGPLDIA","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597257777922},"content":"“Off the beach in most places there are usually sharks,” Chapman said. “It’s like literally a lightning strike.”"},{"_id":"MNK2TZEUTFADHJZGNZW3XJLRF4","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597257777923},"content":"The research, he said, will continue to confront many outstanding questions. Biologists need to learn more about how long environmental DNA lingers in the water and how they can tie DNA results to precise population figures. The Florida International researchers, he said, are working with a group from Florida Atlantic University that uses drones to survey the density of blacktips near West Palm Beach."},{"_id":"4Z4NTLNO5BCWTLP2AHJYWB7JU4","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597257777924},"content":"“It’s very hard to find sharks in actuality. group of researchers has published findings that show blacktip sharks leave DNA in the water -- from feces, skin and mucus -- potentially offering a way to measure their prevalence and manage a key fishery going forward. The science is still a long way from usefulness, as the study team needs to tie levels of DNA found in water samples to specific population counts. drastic move. This move was not caused by my fear of earthquakes but my fear of not having a career in the vocation I adored. Family in tow we trekked cross country, on a plane, and landed at The Tampa Tribune. I am lucky to be one of the few who were plucked by the Tampa Bay Times after the purchase of the Tribune in 2016. My family and I have grown to love the Tampa Bay area. We spend off times floating on the intercostal and biking along the Pinellas Trail. I am extremely passionate about photojournalism and a strong advocate of photojournalism ethics. I am close to completing my second bachelor's degree in photojournalism at Western Kentucky University. I see moments (*nudge nudge, wink wink* my initials are I.C.) that help readers connect with the people in front of my lens. Now I'm thrilled to be the rookie photographer on the multimedia team for my hometown paper. I live in St. Petersburg with my husband, two sons and two geckos. Officers <a href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2020/07/02/oregon-police-trooper-leave-mask-mandate/5370034002/\">have been disciplined for not following state directives to wear masks</a>, but Florida does not have a state-wide order."},{"_id":"KYXPD5BVRBDAVJVCGNBMQKO6SY","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597259723996},"content":"Woods has made some exceptions for officers to wear masks while working at the courthouse, the jail, in public schools, in hospitals and in dealing with people suspected of being infected with COVID-19 or at high risk of complications from the disease."},{"_id":"OH7DPVSFEBBO5CJ3WILN47AAOE","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597259723997},"content":"“For all of these exceptions, the moment that enforcement action is to be taken and it requires you to give an individual orders/commands to comply, the mask will be immediately removed,” Woods said."},{"_id":"KTD35YWONRCDRABXVIBLGVQ37Q","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597259723998},"content":"Woods said deputies who work special details or special events won’t be allowed to wear masks unless it falls under the exceptions he provided."},{"_id":"OS3TDM5HIJDZDJBFUY5UWMLQ7M","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597259723999},"content":"“As for special details and/or any special events (paid or not), masks will not be worn. Effective immediately the entity that has requested and has hired a deputy for a special detail will be given clear instruction by Darian Tucker at the time of their written request that masks will not be worn (unless one of the exceptions above applies). In addition, if you are the special detail deputy you will again advise the contact person that a mask will not be worn by you,” according to the email."},{"_id":"PUUFURE6HFFNZJAXTLHTVKC4WM","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597259724000},"content":"The sheriff said if anyone confronts an employee about them not wearing mask, the employee should “politely and professionally tell them I am not required to wear a mask nor will I, per the Order of the Sheriff,” and walk away."},{"_id":"RAPUEKBAQBBNVCAW7QW234CEVU","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597259724001},"content":"“From that point on it will be my burden and responsibility to take care of the person and answer their problem, complaint or their question,” Woods said."},{"_id":"RXCODYLS4RHSVF6UG4I2GYGRME","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597259724002},"content":"For those visiting a MCSO office, Woods said “effective immediately, any individual walking in to any one of our lobbies (which includes the main office and all district offices) that is wearing a mask will be asked to remove it.” He added, “in light of the current events when it comes to the sentiment and/or hatred toward law enforcement in our country today, this is being done to ensure there is clear communication and for identification purposes of any individual walking into a lobby.”"},{"_id":"BOX33KVVYNHYBF2EQUM36UPTQI","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597259724003},"content":"Woods said MCSO lobbies have barriers that protect employees and the visitors. He said “if a person does not wish to remove the mask they will be asked to leave. If the individual is not comfortable with standing and waiting in the lobby with other individuals, politely ask for their cell number and advise them to stand outside or sit in their vehicle and you will text or call them with their completed transaction.”"},{"_id":"PSS4SOASR5EFRKJ5VZJYYYXL4Y","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597259724004},"content":"Woods said the decision was not easy, and pondered on it for the last two weeks."},{"_id":"R6LYZ4OUKNFSLPAUEQF6TBQQ3Q","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597259724005},"content":"“We can debate and argue all day of why and why not. The fact is, the amount of professionals that give the reason why we should, I can find the exact same amount of professionals that say why we shouldn’t. Since the beginning of this pandemic the operation of this office has not changed and no wearing of masks has been put in place,” he said."},{"_id":"RPIOW2XLWRBLNFOFTOOCWMFTWE","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597259724006},"content":"However, public health officials at local, state and national levels consistently advise that there is clear and mounting evidence that face coverings properly used are among the best methods to reduce the spread of the coronavirus."},{"_id":"INGX4PCM7FFTTEOVQW5QFJHH5A","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597259724007},"content":"Woods said at 900 employees, “our number of cases so far has proven that the current way we are approaching the issue is working.”"},{"_id":"OLCSLATW2NBITFA4WBAXOQ7BGU","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597259724008},"content":"At least 36 employees at the Marion County Jail, and seven outside the jail — including patrol officers — have tested positive for COVID-19. <a href=\"https://www.ocala.com/news/20200722/more-covid-19-at-marion-jail-as-inmates-seek-release\">More than 200 inmates have tested positive</a>. PETERSBURG — A new monument honoring the achievements of the Courageous 12 — a group of Black police officers who won a discrimination lawsuit in the 1960s — is set to be installed at the site of the city’s old police headquarters, according to a news release by city officials."},{"_id":"4S5NYRMNKNDDLLWIWFXLU3SZJU","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597245655991},"content":"The monument, which is included in EDGE Central Development Partner’s bid to build a mixed-use development at the old police station site at 1300 First Ave. N, would follow a plaque the city installed in October, inside the lobby of the new police headquarters across the street. At the time, some felt a plaque wasn’t enough."},{"_id":"5QGMNACXR5EMHLXAPGVML546EI","type":"interstitial_link","additional_properties":{"_id":"IIQKTA56YRGUDDFFKFS4X2MJVY","comments":[]},"url":"https://www.tampabay.com/news/community-news/2020/06/20/the-last-of-the-courageous-12-wants-to-make-sure-the-groups-sacrifice-is-not-forgotten/","content":"RELATED: The last of the ‘Courageous 12′ wants to make sure group’s sacrifice is not forgotten"},{"_id":"HEXMPCWWYZGRTGP2KSFJGUDTRA","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597245655992},"content":"Both the plaque and proposed monument honor the legacies of the 12 police officers who filed the lawsuit in 1965: Leon Jackson, Freddie Lee Crawford, Adam Baker, Raymond DeLoach, Charles Hollands, Robert Keys, Primus Killen, James King, Johnnie B. Lewis, Horace Nero, Jerry Styles and Nathaniel Wooten."},{"_id":"JZRYGZ2RFNH5XBHV5FX24XT26A","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597246781299},"content":"Among their complaints was that Black officers could not patrol white neighborhoods, could not use the same locker room or patrol vehicles as their white colleagues, had little upward mobility in the department and could not drink from the water fountain near the department’s front desk."},{"_id":"5L5VJMGUHFDGHGMABSQ3U3Q5O4","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597245655993},"content":"The men had to take out a bank loan to file their suit, which was dismissed by a federal judge in 1966. However, on Aug. 1, 1968, a federal appeals court sided with the Courageous 12. The victory against discrimination went beyond St. Petersburg, setting a precedent for minorities serving in law enforcement agencies across the nation."},{"_id":"ZWWTQMOKYZGFZGV7SUGRCMXOOE","type":"interstitial_link","additional_properties":{"_id":"44KB7VOEARCJPB7OIQKNQYXW7Q","comments":[]},"url":"https://www.tampabay.com/news/humaninterest/community-pays-tribute-to-st-petersburgs-courageous-12/2231790/","content":"RELATED: Community pays tribute to St. Petersburg's Courageous 12"},{"_id":"PZ3V736XQZDEXCRGBHV4467SWI","type":"text","additional_properties":{"comments":[],"inline_comments":[],"_id":1597245655994},"content":"“We did something for ourselves. ,"budget_line":"The Courageous 12 are known for fully integrating the St. Petersburg Police Department. Back in the 60s, Black officers were only allowed to patrol white neighborhoods. A group of Black officers filed and ultimately won a discrimination lawsuit. After that, they were able to patrol white neighborhoods, too. A monument will honor their history as part of the new development of the old St. Pete Police headquarters building on Central cover the city of St. Petersburg — its residents, leaders and issues. The dramatics of Washington and Tallahassee often overshadow the work of local government, but City Hall is where the decisions are made that have the greatest impact on people’s daily lives. It’s my job to keep it interesting so more people stay engaged with their community. I’m also on the Tampa Bay Times’ hurricane team, and have been deployed to report on the aftermaths of three storms: Hermine in 2016, Irma in 2017 and Michael in 2018. I find serenity in following recipes, the more complicated the better. I’m a bourbon fan, an amatuer pizza critic and a Pinellas Trail bike rider. Otherwise I like watching YouTube and talking on the phone. I’m proudly from New Jersey, don’t @ me for it — or do, it won’t matter. I came to the Times in 2014 after graduating from Northwestern University’s Medill School of Journalism. proud to be a reporter for the Life & Culture team at my hometown paper. My favorite stories explore Florida history and provide context for local oddities, but I also report on breaking news and trends. all over Florida. That last part didn't happen by itself. I was an active volunteer and believe schools should accommodate parents' busy schedules. I’m not a fan of the 3 p.m. parent conference or 10 a.m. PTA meeting! On weekends I play tennis and volunteer at a youth soccer program. Call or email me with your tips about the schools. I use Facebook for family and Twitter for self-promotion.
